Award.AwardTitle: DOCTORAL DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Sophisticated Rejection of Scientific Evidence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific findings and innovations have shaped American life in countless ways, but not all scientific advances have received a warm reception by the public. This project investigates the factors that predict public acceptance or rejection of scientific evidence, focusing on ?sophisticated rejectionists,? individuals who possess the ability to evaluate scientific evidence critically, but still reject the scientific consensus on key issues. The results of the proposed research will identify situations where sophisticated rejection of science is likely, understand how people maintain beliefs contrary to the scientific consensus (e.g., childhood vaccinations) and suggest ways to communicate about science so that it receives a fair hearing.

Scientists take rigorous precautions to ensure the validity of their research and the accuracy of its reporting. However, the public may reject the scientific consensus on an issue (e.g., genetically modified foods) based on factors other than those employed by scientists. This research program examines one possible contributor to such rejection: individuals may lack the skills needed to understand and evaluate scientific evidence. In earlier work, the researcher developed and validated a novel scale measuring nonscientists? scientific reasoning skills (SRS), defined as those needed to assess the validity of scientific results. The present research uses this scale to understand a group of individuals identified in the research to date: ?sophisticated rejectionists,? defined as individuals who have high SRS scores yet still reject the scientific consensus on key issues. The first study will analyze data from the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics? Survey of Public Attitudes Toward and Understanding of Science and Technology, looking for evidence of such sophisticated rejectionists. The second study will investigate how they reject science. Do they fail to apply their skills to dissect spurious scientific arguments or is their interpretation of scientific evidence biased by their belief in claims that most scientists would consider false or incomplete? Two additional studies will test strategies to reduce sophisticated rejection of science by varying how science is communicated. As a whole, this research furthers scientific understanding of how nonscientists evaluate, and sometimes reject, scientific evidence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dissertation research funded by this grant sought to understand when and why nonscientists sometimes appear to reject scientific evidence, for example choosing not to vaccinate children despite the weight of evidence suggesting vaccinations are safe. We were specifically interested in understanding what we call “sophisticated rejection” of science—why do individuals who possess the cognitive skills needed to evaluate science critically sometimes reject that science inappropriately? To investigate these research questions, the dissertation had two main goals. In the first part of the dissertation research, we developed a measurement tool, consisting of a short test, that measures the extent to which an individual possesses the skills needed to assess the quality of scientific evidence, which we call scientific reasoning skills. Having developed this test, we could then use it in surveys and experiments to identify who the “sophisticated rejectionists” were and when they rejected scientific evidence.

 

Our research findings show that scientific understanding, whether measured in terms of scientific reasoning ability, basic scientific knowledge, or scientific educational attainment, can be best thought of as a tool. This tool can be used by nonscientists to understand scientific evidence, but it also to affirm their beliefs or worldview. On polarized scientific topics for which political and religious identities are at stake, nonscientists may be more likely to use their scientific understanding to affirm their identities, leading to situations in which those with greater scientific knowledge are more polarized by identity. But, not all science is polarized, and for these topics, individuals with greater scientific understanding are more likely to accept the science. When individuals are faced with scientific evidence, they are biased in favor of evidence that is consistent with their beliefs. Encouraging individuals to use their scientific reasoning skills fails to reduce the magnitude of this bias. The dissertation research suggests that mistrust and denial of science may have little to do with the science itself, but rather its implications in terms of the beliefs, values, and identities that nonscientists bring with them each time they encounter scientific evidence. The dissertation research suggests that policies that seek to address scientific skepticism must do more than provide science education: in order to succeed, they must also tackle the sometimes non-scientific beliefs that shape the way the public reasons about science. 

 

This grant supported the training and professional development of a graduate student, Drummond, as she proposed and successfully defended her PhD. Drummond disseminated her dissertation research to both academic and non-academic audiences, presenting it at eight conferences over the span of the grant, and publishing two academic papers, with five more papers either under review or in preparation for submission.
